status_message:
From our co-founder and editor Kevin Gosztola:

REFLECTING ON 2016

Shadowproof grew and did remarkably well. The uprising against the Dakota Access Pipeline Project, led by Native Americans, was inspiring. Outside of that, the year was a stream of stench-filled tragedies wrapped in shit-stained farce dropped in a cauldron of gurgling and swirling depravity.

I looked back to see what I wrote a year ago:

"2016 is guaranteed to test every bit of our sanity, but I look forward to spending time ranting, laughing, and playing with all the fantastic people I know, who will make it possible to cope and confront the avalanches and mudslides of insanity, which no matter how hard we try we can scarcely imagine right now."

I am tempted to swap out 2016, replace it with 2017, and share the same sentiment.

I would like to hope the new year will be better. It could not be worse than this year, right? But that is what many thought throughout 2016, and the year just kept getting worse.

There are numerous people frightened about what lies ahead under The Orange Menace's regime. It will be as bad or worse than we imagine if we do not fight back.

If we believe we have no power to stop some of the worst things in store for us in 2017, then we have surrendered to pretty dark forces and only have ourselves to blame for whatever happens.

I am optimistic that there are groups and organizations, which will take important stands and show courage next year. That gives me hope.

Also, the following quote from author Arundhati Roy comes to mind:

"Our strategy should be not only to confront empire, but to lay siege to it. To deprive it of oxygen. To shame it. To mock it. With our art, our music, our literature, our stubbornness, our joy, our brilliance, our sheer relentlessness – and our ability to tell our own stories. Stories that are different from the ones we're being brainwashed to believe."

With that, I look forward to telling stories that need to be told.

I look forward to relentless opposition to all that must be opposed.

I look forward to finding joy in moments when we most need it.

I look forward to art, music, film, and literature that will provoke thought, create empathy, and entertain us.

And most of all, I look forward to mocking those in power and mining their despicable acts for laughs every day.

To all our members and supporters, thanks for your generosity.

Happy New Year.

status_message:
People's historian Howard Zinn recognized, "What matters most is not who is sitting in the White House, but who is sitting in, and who is marching outside the White House, pushing for change."

With the election of Donald Trump, that statement has never been more important.

We cannot let Trump and what his election represents frighten us into submission. We must respond by amping up struggles for economic, racial, environmental, and social justice. That requires journalism, which highlights transformative organizing and scrutinizes the powerful.

Zinn argued government in the hands of Republicans or Democrats typically fails in its responsibilities to citizens until forced to take care of human needs by direct action—like "sit-ins and Freedom Rides for the rights of black people, strikes and boycotts for the rights of workers, mutinies and desertions of soldiers in order to stop a war."

"Voting is easy and marginally useful, but it is a poor substitute for democracy, which requires direct action by concerned citizens," Zinn declared.

There are many who want to do something to fight back against Trump immediately. Under a Trump presidency and a Republican-controlled Congress, journalism and analysis which creates space for dissent and grassroots action will be critical. Shadowproof, along with other outlets, can play a key role in promoting solidarity with those with the audacity to engage in resistance.

Just a small contribution each month goes a very long way. If a few hundred people support us, we can be tremendously effective in our work to elevate social movements that can advance causes and provide a buffer against the worst aspects of Trump's agenda.

Will you support Shadowproof by becoming a member for $5/month? (We'll send you a tote bag to welcome you as a monthly supporter.) https://donate.shadowproof.com/page/contribute/membership
link_name: Become A Shadowproof Member

In this edition: Amnesty International published an extensive report of war crimes by Syrian rebels in Aleppo and Idlib. The rebel groups are backed by the US, Saudi Arabia, Qatar, and Turkey. The Pope called out countries who call for peace but arm the warring parties. Canada is sending troops to join the controversial NATO brigades on the Russian border. A massive suicide attack on a crowded Ramadan market in central Baghdad caused hundreds of deaths and injuries, and massive destruction. Iraqi officials are under intense pressure. Three separate bomb attacks happened in Saudi Arabia by unknown actors, including one near one of the holiest Muslim sites in Medina. 25,000 personnel from 27 nations are involved in the RIMPAC naval exercise, conducted through the month of July.

status_message:
This country has a proud tradition of civil disobedience and resistance. That tradition was carried on at the Trump rally in Chicago, which was shut down.

Media hacks, who are only capable of seeing things in terms of political strategy, can say this will make Trump stronger. People who have a limited grasp of the value of protest can scold activists for "suppressing" free speech.

Fact is, there is a dangerous current of hate in this country, which Trump is amplifying. The media gives Trump obscene amounts of free air time for ratings. Some kind of a mobilization had to set an example for how to come together and repudiate the carnival of bigotry that has been touring this nation.

—Kevin Gosztola

For Hillary Clinton's campaign, this was a miserable day, but for Bernie Sanders' campaign, it could not have unfolded any better:

*Hillary perversely praised Reagans for "starting a conversation" on HIV/AIDS, then apologized claiming she "misspoke"

*State judge issued an order forcing state of Ohio to let 17 year-olds vote if they will be 18 before Election Day; Bernie's campaign had filed federal lawsuit against the state

*Donald Trump's rally was shut down in Chicago, and among the numerous activists and young people, who protested, there were Bernie supporters caught on video chanting after the rally was canceled by Trump. "Bernie! Bernie! Bernie!"

*Bernie Sanders had a rally in Chicago suburb right after Trump's rally was shut down. He was able to show people a clear alternative to Trump—a peaceful rally, where all people are included and there is no incitement to violence

—Kevin Gosztola
The latest news from the Next Cold War.
link_name: Obama Doctrine, Washing Blood From His Hands, British Press Going Ballistic

status_message:
While the Washington Post set the bar for triteness and unfairness toward the Bernie Sanders campaign with 16 articles against Sanders in 16 hours, the Chicago Tribune might become a runner-up for most anti-Sanders newspaper in the country.

Here's a sentence from a piece of hackery bashing Sanders for his statements on free trade. It's by Steve Chapman: "If Michiganders went to Wal-Mart or Home Depot tomorrow and found the shelves stripped of everything made abroad, they would quickly grasp the upside of free trade." It's like Chapman heard this line on a U.S. Chamber of Commerce conference call, thought it was clever, and stole it.

The Tribune so despises the Sanders campaign push for programs that would make America more like most industrialized democracies (see Michael Moore's "Where to Invade Next") that the Tribune editorial board would not endorse Sanders. It would not endorse Clinton either because Clinton is mimicking Sanders' message to save her campaign from tanking. So, the editorial board endorsed the failed campaign of Marco Rubio, and hysterically did so as they claimed to have a better grasp of what's realistic than the Democratic candidates.

This is going to escalate as we get closer to the Illinois primary on Tuesday. The hacky columns will be real doozies.

—Kevin Gosztola
We are committed to challenging inaccurate and disingenuous reporting among establishment media.
link_name: Countering The Establishment Media Narrative During The 2016 Election

status_message:
The people of Michigan defied the Nate Silver/Vox-ification of U.S. elections, and huge turnouts led to a victory for Bernie Sanders. Silver's Five Thirty Eight wrongly predicted Hillary Clinton had  a more than 99% chance of winning Michigan. So, this plunges media pundits into an even greater existential crisis than they were previously experiencing, and let me tell you: it won't get better from here.

Clinton widened her lead today because she blew Sanders out in Mississippi. However, the surprise upset in Michigan signals this race is far, far from over.

Now, here are the tallies for the Democratic primary: Clinton has 760 pledged delegates, Sanders has 546 pledged delegates. (These are the truthful and accurate counts. Any other counts include super delegates and are misleading.)

—Kevin Gosztola
ICYMI: We take a look at how media outlets include "super delegates" in delegate counts and misleadingly fuel perception that Bernie Sanders has no chance. #MichiganPrimary

status_message:
Shadowproof Events is a web-based series where authors discuss some of the most critical issues of our time.

Shadowproof Events are live video chats with our writers and an author. Anyone in attendance can ask questions by text chat or Twitter.

Shadowproof members get free access to all our events, but you can buy tickets for just $5.

TICKETS: https://donate.shadowproof.com/page/contribute/sp-events

Shadowproof Membership: https://donate.shadowproof.com/page/contribute/membership

Up next, Kevin Gosztola talks with Antony Loewenstein, author of "Disaster Capitalism: Making A Kiling Out Of Catastrophe":

Best-selling journalist Antony Loewenstein trav­els across Afghanistan, Pakistan, Haiti, Papua New Guinea, the United States, Britain, Greece, and Australia to witness the reality of disaster capitalism. He discovers how companies such as G4S, Serco, and Halliburton cash in on or­ganized misery in a hidden world of privatized detention centers, militarized private security, aid profiteering, and destructive mining.

Disaster has become big business. Talking to immigrants stuck in limbo in Britain or visiting immigration centers in America, Loewenstein maps the secret networks formed to help cor­porations bleed what profits they can from economic crisis. He debates with Western contractors in Afghanistan, meets the locals in post-earthquake Haiti, and in Greece finds a country at the mercy of vulture profiteers. In Papua New Guinea, he sees a local commu­nity forced to rebel against predatory resource companies and NGOs.

What emerges through Loewenstein's re­porting is a dark history of multinational corpo­rations that, with the aid of media and political elites, have grown more powerful than national governments. In the twenty-first century, the vulnerable have become the world's most valu­able commodity.
link_name: Shadowproof Event: Disaster Capitalism with Antony Loewenstein

status_message:
Shadowproof invites you to attend a web-based event series with authors on some of the most critical issues of our time.

Shadowproof members get free access to all our events, but you can buy tickets for just $5. See link above.

Up next, Kevin Gosztola talks with Kris Hermes, the author of "Crashing the Party":

Over the past fifteen years, people in the United States—and dissidents in particular—have witnessed a steady escalation of the National Security State, including invasive surveillance and infiltration, indiscriminate police violence, and unlawful arrests. These concerted efforts to spy on Americans and undermine meaningful social change are greatly enhanced by the coordination of numerous local, state, and federal agencies often operating at the behest of private corporations. Normally associated with the realities of a post-9/11 world, "Crashing the Party" shows how these developments were already being set in motion during the Republican National Convention (RNC) protests in 2000. It also documents how, in response, dissidents confronted new forms of political repression by pushing legal boundaries and establishing new models of collective resistance.

"Crashing the Party" explains how the events of 2000 acted as a testing ground in which Philadelphia Police Commissioner John Timoney was able to develop repressive methods of policing that have been used extensively across the U.S. ever since. At the same time, these events also provided a laboratory for the radical, innovative, and confrontational forms of legal support carried out by R2K Legal, a defendant-led collective that raised unprecedented amounts of money for legal defense, used a unique form of court solidarity to overcome hundreds of serious charges, and implemented a PR campaign that turned the tide of public opinion in favor of dissidents. While much has been written about the global-justice era of struggle, little attention has been paid to the legal struggles of the period or the renewed use of solidarity tactics in jail and the courtroom that made them possible. By analyzing the successes and failures of these tactics, "Crashing the Party" offers rare insight into the mechanics and concrete effects of such resistance. In this way, it is an invaluable resource for those seeking to confront today's renewed counterintelligence tactics.
link_name: Shadowproof Events: Crashing The Party by Kris Hermes

link_name: Death Of Paul Castaway Highlights Denver's Overlooked Police Brutality Problem

status_message:
"You're fucking killing me!" That's what 70 year old prisoner Timothy Strayer told Dearborn County Detention Center officials when he couldn't breathe, yet they still refused to give him oxygen.

John Kiriakou was the only person to go to prison for torture by the Central Intelligence Agency -- but only because he blew the whistle on the torturers! At Firedoglake, we published his groundbreaking prison letters.

We're looking forward to more support of whistleblowers & truth tellers at Shadowproof.
